Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 06:23AM GoldenGirls wrote: My mother went through this and still continues to with her bone mets. What we have learned is that no scan is completely accurate for the detection or monitoring of bone mets. Some scans are better than others for picking up different types of bone lesions (blastic or lytic) and none can be completely counted on to detect very small lesions or changes. My mother's onc is head of oncology at the cancer center and leads a research team.He goes by her symptoms more than scans. Her bone mets diagnosis came from a CT and bone scan, followed by 3 biopsies because getting the right sample from bone is also difficult. Demand a different type of scan even if your bone scan was clear. It will put your mind at ease. Good luck!

Posts.Content: GoldenGirls wrote: My mother is still in horrible pain and it's been going on for months. No one knows for sure what is causing it so finding the right meds to get it under control has been a nightmare so far. She was convinced it was from Zometa, but has now been off it for a few months and the pain continues. It was happening while she was stable and is still happening with progression. (She switches to Faslodex from Aromasin tomorrow). The thing that has the doctors stumped is the pattern of the pain since it doesn't seem to jive with mets pain, especially since it was already happening when her cancer was stable/regressing in some areas. So, she asked me to share an example of her "pain pattern" here and see if anyone here has experienced something similar and what medication she could try next for the pain. This is an example of how her pain has been going for months now: November 1- 9: Severe pain in rib and right shoulder. November 9: pain in rib and shoulder much better but new pain in upper thigh November 10 - 21: severe pain in upper thigh all the way down to the knee - can't walk most days, pain very bad November 22: pain in thigh much better, now pain in lower back on other side starting November 23 - December 2: severe pain in lower back, can't stand or sit too long December 2 - back pain getting better December 4 - 13: severe pain in left shoulder, no pills make it better The pain stays in each place for around 10 days and as it improves another pops up in a totally different part of the body and stays the same amount of time. This pattern has continued for months and most of the time she is in debilitating pain. Some of them feel worse upon getting up and ease up with movement while others get worse with movement. She says some feel like bone pain (deep aching that almost feels like the bone is cold) and others are like the burning muscle pain like you'd feel after a very intense workout. She had a bone density test which was normal and the doctor doesn't see signs of osteoporosis or bone loss.  Anyone experience this sort of pain and have any idea what it was from? Sorry for the long post. I'm typing what she is asking and being as detailed as possible :) Mom was originally dx in 10/2001. Mets to bones and 2 supraclavicular nodes in 01/2013. Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2014 05:06PM GoldenGirls wrote: It seems that you are already doing everything that you can to get to the bottom of this and as hard as it is to wait for the appointment, it isn't going to change anything to get upset about it. I feel for you because I know what it's like to worry about health issues, especially having seen others close to me go through cancer. I can tell you that anxiety disorder can make you feel physical symptoms, so any pain that you are having from your breast/armpit can easily be feeling much worse because of your anxiety about it. I can't believe how many symptoms I have ended up with after working myself into a tizzy over something. It was especially bad after a friend died from cervical cancer at a very young age. I was so upset and so scared that every last little thing I felt sent a jolt of sheer terror through me, sending me into a panic. By the time my test results were in I was hysterical just walking into the doctor's office only to find out that I was fine. I have to stop myself often from letting the fear from my mother's breast cancer carry me away because it so easily gets the better of me and before I know it I am convinced that I am feeling every symptom that I have read about in relation to breast cancer. Anxiety, fear, and stress can have a major toll on our physical health and make us feel actual pain and other physical symptoms. The best thing that we can do is be vigilant about our health which you are already doing by having the lump checked out. It's not easy but knowing that you are already doing everything you can has to bring you some peace of mind or you'll just drive yourself nuts. Take it from someone who's been there...more than once. Beesie gave you a lot of good information and valid reasons to stay positive. Hugs

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2015 04:53AM GoldenGirls wrote: I would trust my mother's onc with my life, as I do with hers. I always have questions when I am not at an appointment with her when a decision is made, but it's more for my own understanding of what's happening and what to expect than not trusting him. He's been her onc for over 14 years now and his instincts have always been spot-on even. When first dx with mets, she had 3 negative biopsies. This of course made us want to believe that it wasn't mets. He didn't settle for what the biopsy results were saying because his experience told him otherwise and he persisted, even sternly telling the doctor doing the final biopsy to "get it right this time and get a good sample from the lesion". Thank god for his instinct, experience, and persistence because it was indeed mets. His experience and instincts were right again when my mom's pain changed and her scans were still showing stable. He didn't push her to switch treatments right away but did warn that her symptoms have always been a better indicator of progression in her case than CT and MRI. He was right again...and again since that. So far her scans don't show changes until the progression is significant. (They don't use PET here) He is very aware of balancing treatment for the best results and keeping her quality of life as good as possible and will be the first to recommend a change or a break if he feels that her side effects could become a problem. Just wish I could get her to stop downplaying side effects! I'll never stop asking questions because I want to know as much as possible--likely because it makes me feel better and like I have some sort of control)--but I trust that every decision he makes in regard to her care is the best for her at the time. I figure he didn't get to be head of oncology and lead the research team for nothing. ;)

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2013 11:22AM GoldenGirls wrote: Hi Grace2u, I think I shared my mom's story with you earlier this week. We were thrilled when the first and then the second biopsy came back negative, but the onc was convinced the samples must have been "missing something" even though they were guided biopsies because lytic lesions are very often malignant. Her bone density test just a couple months earlier showed perfectly strong bones and they are still very hard and strong despite the lytic lesions. It  wasn't the answer we wanted and we really did hold out hope over those 3 months that it was going to be something other than cancer, but now we're grateful that the onc didn't just accept the negative biopsy and persisted. He told me point blank that even with the 2 negative biopsies that he was certain it was cancer and that a better sample would confirm it. He was right. My mom's follow-up scan done the same week as the 3rd biopsy showed that one of the lesions had grown (and become significantly more painful). The onc said that an open/surgical biopsy might be the only way to get a sufficient sample. That was going to be our next step if the 3rd didn't confirm it. Maybe that's an option for your daughter? I hope you get the answers you need and I pray that they're benign.

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2013 08:12PM GoldenGirls wrote: Countingdays - Thank you for the kind words. My mom's treatment out here has been pretty stellar thanks to an amazing oncologist who has cared for her since her original diagnosis. He may not be the chattiest of oncs and may have the kind of demeanor that puts some people off, but he is thorough and persistent and if it wasn't for him we would have probably accepted her first few negative biopsies and not gotten her the treatment she needed. Alberta is beautiful! I used to be a flight attendant and spent quite a bit of time in different parts of your province. Always a great time :) Alyon - My mom was diagnosed Stage III and went 11 years before her cancer mets appeared. Hers also seemed to come out of the blue. She had no history of breast cancer in the family (one possible ovarian cancer in an aunt) and she had regular mammograms which were fine. We believed that since she had gone a decade without recurrence that she was in the clear. Not so. It seems to be a crapshoot though as some go so long without a recurrence, some never have a recurrence, and then others with a good prognosis find themselves with a recurrence months later. We just don't know and have to realize that worrying about it doesn't help and only takes away from enjoying life and those we love. I know it's easier said than done, but like Michael J. Fox once said:  "If you imagine the worst case scenario and it happens, you've lived it twice." Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2013 10:02AM - edited Jun 24, 2013 10:12AM by GoldenGirls Hello all. My question is for those with bone mets. Does new pain always mean progression? My mom was diagnosed a few months back with mets in her clavicle bone, T5, L3, L5, sacrum, and illiac. She had rads to the clavicle (for pain) and the T5 (to avoid further damage/compression). She has been on Exemestane (generic Aromasin) since February and monthly Aredia for her bones. Other than hot flashes and joint pains from the meds, she has been feeling great...until this past week. She is having low back pain that she describes as feeling like severe muscle pain as well as shoulder pain. We don't know if this could be from the mets or something else entirely as it feels different from the pain she was having when first diagnosed. Her shoulder only hurts when she tries to lift her arm, though if she "pushes the joint" she can lift it all the way without pain. As for her back, she flopped down on the couch last week and felt a VERY sharp pain that only lasted a few seconds down in her lower back. For the next few days the pain was on both sides of her lower back and bad on sitting an standing but fine otherwise. Now she only feels it when she turns over in bed. Advil makes the pain in the back and shoulder much better, but doesn't take it away completely. It sounds like progression, doesn't it? She's had odd aches and pains in her joints and muscles since starting treatment and they last a couple of days and go away. Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2012 08:54AM - edited Dec 13, 2012 09:07AM by GoldenGirls It'll be a month tomorrow since my mom started her turn on the "is it mets?" rollercoaster and we still don't really know what's happening. I know some of you ladies have been following along with my posts and a couple have messaged me about her situation so here's what happened. - Extremely painful shoulder and swollen clavicle - the size of a tennis ball with extra swelling around it. - Emergency dept. xrays and bloodwork all clear, but doctor was convinced the swollen clavicle must be a tumor because of my mom's history of cancer so she ordered a CT scan the next day. Scan came back showing 3 lytic lesions (clavicle head, sacrum, illiac bone) and a couple other things that apparantly are of no concern even though the ER doctor told us with absolute certainty that my mom is "full of cancer" and that it can't be anything else causing those lesions. - Onc examines her the following week and is perplexed by the swelling and the fact that she had this same thing--though not as severe--happen a few months earlier and resolve itself. Also surprised by her clear xray and blood work. - Ultrasound done on the swollen clavicle and surrounding area - ends up showing nothing not even the soft tissue denisty originally reported in CT scan. - Had bone scan done, not sure about the specifics of the results yet but onc says his concern is only the 3 lytic lesions so I am guessing they showed up on the bone scan. - Biopsy is done on a slightly swollen supraclavicular lymph node on the opposite side of her swelling which also happens to be the side of her original breast cancer 11 years ago. Results found nothing wrong. So the onc called her last night to let her know that she will be going for a bone biopsy to try to figure out the cause of those 3 lytic lesions. He is not concerned by anything else on that original CT scan (3mmx6mm lung nodule and sclerotic lesion in pelvis area). I think it's good news that the lymph node was clear and that whatever is going on in the clavicle bone hasn't affected the soft tissue like they originally suspected,right? I just thought that between the CT, Xray and bone scan that they would have a better idea as to whether or not those lytic lesions are malignant especially since I know that many of the ladies here had their bone mets diagnosed with only scans and not a biopsy. This is nuts!

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2014 11:08AM GoldenGirls wrote: My mom's last bought of progression in her bones was significant and made her anemic, along with taking away her appetite. She was taken off treatment for a few weeks before starting the next and opted to treat the anemia through diet (was willing to go on meds if it didn't get better). She started eating more, including eating even when she wasn't hungry. She increased her intake of red meat and started eating cereal every morning that was high in iron. I don't recall the specific cereal she was eating, but after reading labels she found one that had 50 percent of the recommended daily intake per serving. Eating regularly and including foods that were high in iron did the trick and within a couple of weeks her blood counts returned to normal. She started Xeloda after that and has been fine since. I hope that helps. Hugs

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2012 02:04PM GoldenGirls wrote: My grandmother is a walking miracle. At just over 96, my grandmother who was raised in a tiny village in Portugal has never had an overnight stay in a hospital except to give birth to my mom and my uncle. She worked like a horse most of her life. She eats thick white toast with loads of margarine and a cup of coffee for breakfast, a HEAPING plate of fried everything for lunch - french fries, fried sausage, fried eggs and even dips a piece of bread in the oil in the pan to "add flavor" to it! She washes it down with a beer mug full of red wine--sometimes more and then eats cake or pastries for dinner with more coffee. After dinner she also enjoys a nightcap of whisky or some sweet liqueur and will have another cookie or pastry if she's up late. She stays up late and wakes up early. She won't say no to chips or booze and at well under 5 feet tall, she weighs about 140lbs most of which she carries in her waistline and belly. She has never had a mammogram or pelvic exam EVER and other than the occasional bought of high blood pressure, which seems to be brought on by imaginary arguments with my dead grandfather, she has never been on any meds or suffered from any medical conditions... unless you count the antibiotics for an infected blister she got from wearing a pair of tight new high heels, which she still rocks on a daily basis! She travels to her country and back here to Canada every summer for 4 months by herself and does all of her own cooking and cleaning. I often wonder what disease lurks in her body, especially when I see her ginormous breasts -- one of which is considerably bigger than the other and always has been - at least in my lifetime. I have heard her tell the story of the "big bump" she had cut open and drained after giving birth to my uncle and how it never troubled her again and wonder if it was cancer. It was close to 60 years ago and there were no biopsies or any of that where she lived. She was awake for the process and not given any medication and instead held down by 2 other nurses to keep her still while the doctor cut it open. Maybe ignorant bliss is the way to go for some. Every little ache or pain has always been brushed off by her as age or not a big deal. Who knows what's going on in that body, but at 96+ and still going strong after doing all of the wrong things, she is described by every doctor she meets as "walking miracle".

Posts.Title: Do You Get Swelling from Your Bone Mets? GoldenGirls GoldenGirls

Posts.Content: GoldenGirls wrote: My mom had been cancer-free for 11 years since her stage 3 dx. She developed a sore shoulder and swelling in the clavicle so we went to ER. The doctor ordered xrays of the neck and chest and they were all clear. After we mentioned her previous breast cancer a CT scan was ordered of her neck, chest and abdomen and the results showed 3 lesions in 3 different joints "appear to be consitent with metastatic breast cancer" and one "oblong nodule on the lung, 3mm x 4mm that will require futher investigation" because they don't know what it is. There was also mention that the clavicle swelling could be from a damaged lymph node but they weren't sure. The doctor went on to give her 2 cents and say that she "doesn't believe it can be mets from a cancer from 11 years ago so it must be all new cancers, maybe even myeloma (?) or possibly lymphoma"! I understand that BC could come back after this many years and does for many! She got quite defensive when i mentioned having read on several occasions that CT scan alone was not the best way to dx bone mets and that since they all appear to be in joints could it possibly be my mother's degerative disease showing up. She said no, turned the sheet over and waved it at me and said Um, no it's pretty clear what they think it is". Has anyone had a CT show possible mets that turned out to be something else? I know I have read a couple of experiences on here and wonder how common it is. And yes, I sure wish that's all it is as we wait for some more definitive info from the onc on Thursday! Mom was originally dx in 10/2001. Mets to bones and 2 supraclavicular nodes in 01/2013. She passed away from complications from bone metastases Dec 2016. Log in to post a reply

She watched my father go from seemingly healthy to dying from cancer within a couple of months and even though the situation was entirely different (inoperable large primary brain tumor that was caught very late), that is what she associates stage 4 with and until the onc tells her otherwise she is in a pretty dark place and only trying to hold it together for everyone else. it breaks my heart. I know that ultrasounds don't pick up bones, but is it good news that there is no actual soft tissue tumor or enlarged lymph node on the side they were most concerned about?? Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2016 09:03PM GoldenGirls wrote: I'm sorry you've been having such a rough time. My mother has just finally gotten past a bad stretch similar to yours. Scans showed stable but after more investigation they found a fracture in her sacrum. She had 10 rads to the area (sacrum and lower spine). Her new pain meds made her feel sick and barely touched the pain and she ended up taking her pain meds to close together because of the bad pain that she ended up ODing which causes dizziness, extreme fatigue, and vomiting. After rads she was too tired to do anything and just feeling terrible and this was even before starting her new chemo. Turns out the rads to the pelvis very commonly cause anemia so on top of everything else her counts dropped considerably which explained the extreme fatigue. Slowly but surely she's gotten back to feeling better again. Have they checked your blood recently? Anemia can cause extreme fatigue, loss of appetite, GI issues, heart palpitations...all kinds of symptoms. Hope your onc is able to get to the bottom of it for you.

Posts.Content: GoldenGirls wrote: We went to see the onc about my mother's latest scan results and are a little confused. The bone scan report said that there appears to be significant progression with uptake in various spots throughout the body where there was no activity before. (Is this what tumour flare is?) The CT scan indicated that there was significant bone loss in the T10 that wasn't there before but her lymph nodes are stable, and that's it. He told us that the activity in the bones on the scan could be the result of the zometa and that bone scans can't be relied on because many things look like cancer on them. His only real concern was the change in the T10 and he told us that if she was experiencing pain in that area he would be more compelled to think it was the cancer, but with her nodes and tumor markers stable and her lack of pain there that he can't say for sure there's progression because bone mets are tricky and imaging is not reliable for bone mets. He said it's possible that her age (63) and treatment could be causing osteoporosis and that the t10 could be the result of that. He also told her what he said at the start of all of this last year - that he would go by her nodes (which regressed after the start of treatment and are stable), by her blood work, and by her symptoms, as well as any changes in nodes or progression to organs on her CT scans and MRIs. She is still having severe pain even though it's been 7 weeks since her last zometa which seems to be the cause of her pain and he doesn't want to stop her current treatment (aromasin) if it's still working, which he feels it is. Does this make any sense? I tend to ramble. What we want to know is if anyone else has experienced/been told that more spots on the bone scan are the result of treatment working or from zometa and not progression...even though the scan looks like it is? * I should add that I am probably not explaining this all that well and that her onc is head of oncology and cancer research at the cancer centre. He has also been her onc since her original dx 12 years ago. He has been on the money with everything, including persisting on getting a dx of mets even when multiple biopsies came back negative. Just wondering how common this is. Mom was originally dx in 10/2001. Mets to bones and 2 supraclavicular nodes in 01/2013. She passed away from complications from bone metastases Dec 2016. All we know is that her 2 biopsies were negative. My mom is willing to proceed with an open (surgical) biopsy if needed and he is also thorough enough that he will likely suggest further testing. She had a scare a few years back with suspicious spots on her liver on an ultrasound. He immediately sent her for a CT which showed nothing, but still wanted to be certain and also sent her for an MRI, which thankfully was also clear. I am happy to say that he isn't the type to let something go unless he is very confident in what he has found. It would be nice to just take those negative results and put this all behind us, but I am far too aware of the consequences of missing something and don't want my mother to wake up one day with no options because things are too far gone. Will update later.

All we know is that the ER doctor sent all of the reports to his practice as well as to his hospital office (he is head of oncology in a city 2 hours away where we use to live). I know it'll be easier to handle when we know more and know how we are going to proceed. I really hope he is able to see her quickly. Part of me is still praying that the lesions they found are degenertive disease as she does have that in multiple joints and all of the bone lesions found were on joints. They weren't able to determine what's going on in the lung except that there is an "oblong non-specific nodule 3mm by 4mm that requires further investigation". i know that other conditions can be mistaken for bone mets and I don't understand how none of these showed up in her initial xrays or even in her bone density test 3-4 months ago which, according to the ER doctor, "should have at least caught the one in her hip if it was there at the time". I would love to be able to print some off and give them to my mom to read to keep her spirits up until she has more information. xo

Posts.Content: May 9, 2017 01:28PM GoldenGirls wrote: I am not a doctor or medical professional, but as a daughter who was with her mom through 15+ years of breast cancer, I can tell you that you should get a second opinion if you are still concerned, especially given that the doctor made his concern clear. Needle biopsies are more likely to "miss" a cancer than an excisional biopsy. Having the lump removed and tested, if possible, would give you the certainty you need. I understand what you mean about wanting to accept the good news and be happy about it and still having concerns. My mom's experience with false negative biopsy results are different as she was waiting to confirm if her cancer had spread when it happened to her. She had 3 biopsies that were negative but her oncologist (highly experienced and reputable) insisted that he felt they were missing the right area. This upset us because we so badly wanted to believe that the negative results were right, but as he put it "if it walks like a duck and talks like a duck, then it's probably a duck". Thank God he persisted because my mother's cancer was indeed back. This is not to say that your mom's results are wrong, but if you are having any doubts then it is worth pushing for an excisional biopsy or a second opinion from a breast specialist. Praying that you get the answers and peace you need.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2015 07:19AM GoldenGirls wrote: My mother's results all showed stable, but a fracture in the sacrum has the onc questioning whether it's something she's done/wear and tear on already damaged bones, or if Xeloda is failing after 18+ months. He has sent her for radiation to the sacrum and lower spine and will re-scan her after rads before deciding if she will switch treatments. So the news is confusing, but we're still hanging onto the fact that 5 scans in the past 6 months still show stable. I know bone mets are hard to track on scans of any kind, but fingers are still crossed. Unfortunately, we had a not so great experience at the cancer center we were sent to for radiation. The radiation oncologist and his nurse were both incredibly negative. Okay, more like the angels of death! My mother, until this fracture and resulting pain episode, has not been on any pain meds in the 3 years since her stage IV dx. Even now, she's content taking Advil when she does have pain. This sent the nurse into a fit! She lectured us about the severity of her cancer and talked over her when my mother tried to explain that she'd been pretty much pain free up until this. The nurse repeatedly said "You NEED to understand that you have metastatic disease and it is only getting worse". She also kept talking about how she should "take something at night because cancer hurts more at night and not sleeping isn't helping anyone" -- this even though my mother repeatedly told her that she actually feels better at night because she is not putting any weight on the hip/leg and therefore sleeps great. It was infuriating! Then the rad onc came in, and while very friendly, he too jumped to conclusions about my mother's pain and ability to live her daily life, even saying to her that she needs to put her mother (my grandmother who lives with her) in a home. I swear he was on the verge of suggesting hospice or some kind of facility for my mother until we both jumped in and informed him that my grandmother is entirely self-sufficient and doesn't actually require my mom's physical care. If anything having my grandmother with her has been a great help because she cooks and helps with basic things so my mom can rest her hip. My mother also had to remind him several times that until this fracture, she's been very active and feeling great. She felt dismissed and completely misunderstood because the nurse and onc both made the assumption that her extensive mets mean she must be completely incapacitated and on her last leg. Did I mention she still only has bone mets as of last scan? I wanted to grab their tongues to stop them from saying anything else and actually listening to us! It seems that not being in hysterics gave them the impression that we don't understand the severity of her disease. Jeez. An infuriating experience that we'll try to put behind us as she starts her radiation next week. Wishing everyone great results!
